item.title: Air Canada Flight Makes Rough Landing in Nova Scotia
item.description: Flight 624 crash-landed at the Halifax airport early Sunday morning, causing a widespread power outage after clipping utility poles on entry. No major injuries were immediately reported.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH ROSEN

item.title: Australia to Join Regional Development Bank Led by China
item.description: The decision to join the bank is an about-face for the nation, which had earlier agreed with the Obama administrationâ€™s requests to stay aloof from the bank.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Residents in Eastern Ukraine City Rally Against Separatism
item.description: The participants from Dnepropetrovsk had hoped to help mend a rift between President Petro O. Poroshenko and the regional governor he fired and to ease worries that Ukraine is also now at risk of unraveling into privately ruled fiefs.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Too Ill to Fly? Shifting Ideas of Pilot Fitness
item.description: Aviation experts say that most screening programs in Europe and the United States are based on an honor system that relies on pilots volunteering information about their mental health.
item.dc:creator: ERICA GOODE and JAD MOUAWAD
item.media:description: A priest walked past candles before a Mass in memory of the victims of the Germanwings Flight 9525 crash, in Dignes-les-Bains, southeastern France, on Friday.

item.title: Afghanistanâ€™s Supreme Court Sentences Journalistâ€™s Killer
item.description: The court ruled that a police officer convicted of murdering an Associated Press photographer, Anja Niedringhaus, should serve 20 years in prison, according to documents sent to the countryâ€™s attorney general.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Iranâ€™s Top Negotiator Says Accord Can Be Drafted
item.description: Mohammad Javad Zarif, the Iranian foreign minister, said Saturday that he had had productive discussions with his European counterparts about the remaining gaps in a nuclear accord.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Indefinite Safe Sex Urged for Liberian Ebola Survivors
item.description: After an Ebola death, scientists want to gather more information on the length of time the virus might remain present in semen.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK

item.title: Ex-Yemeni Leader Urges Truce and Successorâ€™s Ouster
item.description: In a 10-minute address broadcast on Yemeni television, Ali Abdullah Saleh called for elections to choose a new president.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and SAEED AL-BATATI

item.title: News Analysis: Fragile Cease-Fire in Ukraine Inspires Little Confidence in West
item.description: Western diplomats and analysts are predicting a further escalation of tensions, possibly including the placement of Russian nuclear weapons in the annexed Crimean Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Insurgents Seize Much of Key Syrian City
item.description: A coalition of Islamist insurgents, including a branch of Al Qaeda, seized most of the northern Syrian city of Idlib on Saturday after four days of heavy fighting.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: 2 Czech Tourists Abducted in 2013 Have Been Freed in Pakistan
item.description: The release of the two women from the Czech Republic, who were kidnapped from a bus in Pakistan by gunmen, was negotiated by a Turkish humanitarian organization.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Germanwings Pilot Andreas Lubitz Sought Treatment for Vision Problems Before Crash, Authorities Say
item.description: The revelation adds a new element to the portrait of the German co-pilot, who officials say was also being treated for psychological issues.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY, NICHOLAS KULISH, NICOLA CLARK and JACK EWING

item.title: Nigeria Votes in Sharply Contested Presidential Election
item.description: Dense crowds of people sometimes waited hours to vote on Saturday, and the election had to be extended to Sunday in parts of the country where machinery malfunctioned.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: People waited to register to vote in the presidential election outside a polling center in Kano, Nigeria, on Saturday morning.

item.title: Sri Lankan Presidentâ€™s Brother Dies From Ax Wounds
item.description: President Maithripala Sirisenaâ€™s youngest brother, Priyantha Sirisena, known as Sand King for his sand mining business, was assaulted two days earlier.
item.dc:creator: DHARISHA BASTIANS

item.title: Somali Troops End Siege at Hotel as Death Toll Rises to 15
item.description: An elite counterterrorism unit rescued 50 hostages in an episode that left dead five attackers, said to be from the Shabab, the militant Islamist group.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED IBRAHIM
item.media:description: Somali soldiers on Saturday in Mogadishu outside the Maka al-Mukarama Hotel, where Shabab fighters killed 15 people.

item.title: Iraqi Forces in No Hurry to Expel ISIS From Tikrit
item.description: In the wake of American airstrikes on Islamic State positions in the city, there seemed to be little urgency to make progress on the ground.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Iraqi forces fired at the Islamic State in Tikrit on Saturday. Islamic State fighters continued to hold the center of the city.

item.title: No. 2 Negotiators in Iran Talks Argue Physics Behind Politics
item.description: Forty years after they both attended M.I.T., the nuclear scientists Ernest J. Moniz and Ali Akbar Salehi have emerged as the No. 2 negotiators on Iranâ€™s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:credit: Fabrice Coffrini/Agence France-Presse â€” Getty Images
item.media:description: Energy Secretary Ernest J. Moniz during a break from negotiations in Lausanne, Switzerland.

item.title: In Brazil, Some Inmates Get Therapy With Hallucinogenic Tea
item.description: The provision of ayahuasca, a psychedelic brew used in the Amazon basin for centuries, to inmates on short furloughs reflects a quest to ease pressure on Brazilâ€™s prison system.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prisoners on short furloughs danced with other congregants at a temple in Ji-ParanÃ¡, in Brazilâ€™s Amazon basin, after consuming ayahuasca, a psychedelic drink used in various religions.

item.title: Healing Fire in Londonderry: The Temple Was Built to Burn
item.description: Burning a 75-foot-tall pagan temple in a Republican Catholic enclave on the loyalist Protestant side of Londonderry seemed to many like a bad idea.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors inside the 75-foot temple in Londonderry, Northern Ireland, a city with long Catholic and Protestant divisions.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Turning a Wrongful Imprisonment Into Advocacy
item.description: Eric Volz turned a wrongful conviction in Nicaragua into a vocation, helping other Americans imprisoned overseas.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
item.media:description: "A lot of people were convinced I was guilty. But there's only one truth. Facts are facts," said Eric Volz.
